sections.paragraphs:
{{Tanakh OT|Nevi'im|prophetic}}

The '''Book of Amos ''' is the third of the [[Twelve Minor Prophets]] in the [[Tanakh]]/[[Old Testament]] and the second in the Greek [[Septuagint]] tradition.{{sfn|Sweeney|2000|p=unpaginated}} [[Amos (prophet)|Amos]], an older contemporary of [[Hosea]] and [[Isaiah]],<ref name ="Harris">[[Stephen L Harris|Harris, Stephen L.]], ''Understanding the Bible''. Palo Alto: Mayfield. 1985.</ref> was active c. 750 BC during the reign of [[Jeroboam II]]<ref name="Harris"/> (788–747 BC),<ref>Finkelstein, Israel. ''The Forgotten Kingdom: The Archaeology and History of Ancient Israel.'' Atlanta: SBL, 2013. Ancient Near East Monographs, Number 5. p. 4.</ref> making Amos the first prophetic book of the Bible to be written. Amos lived in the [[kingdom of Judah]] but preached in the northern [[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|kingdom of Israel]].<ref name="Harris"/> His major themes of [[social justice]], God's [[omnipotence]], and [[divine judgment]] became staples of prophecy.<ref name="Harris"/>

sections.title: Structure
sections.paragraphs:

(Michael D. Coogan, ''A Brief Introduction to the Old Testament'', 2009, p. 256.)
*Oracles against the nations (1.3–2.6)
*Addresses to groups in Israel
**Women of Samaria (4.1–3)
**Rich persons in Samaria (6.1–7)
**Rich persons in Jerusalem (8.4–8)
*Five symbolic visions of God's judgment on Israel, interrupted by a confrontation between Amos and his listeners at Bethel (7.10–17):
**Locusts (7.1–3)
**Fire (7.4–6)
**A plumb line (7.7–9)
**A basket of fruit (8.1–3)
**God beside the altar (9.1–8a)
*Epilogue 9:8b–15

sections.title: Summary
sections.paragraphs: The book opens with a historical note about the prophet, then a short oracle announcing [[Yahweh]]'s judgment (repeated in the [[Book of Joel]]).{{sfn|Coogan|2008|p=84}} The prophet denounces the crimes against humanity committed by the gentile (non-Jewish) nations, tells Israel that even they have sinned and are guilty of the same crimes, and report five symbolic visions prophesying the destruction of Israel.{{sfn|O'Brien|1990|pp=26–27}} Included in this, with no apparent order, are an oracle on the nature of prophecy, snippets of hymns, oracles of woe, a third-person prose narrative concerning the prophet, and an oracle promising restoration of the House of David, which had not yet fallen in the lifetime of Amos.{{sfn|Coogan|2008|p=84}}

sections.title: Composition
sections.paragraphs:
[[Amos (prophet)|Amos]] prophesied during the reign of [[Jeroboam II]], King of [[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|Israel]], and of [[Uzziah]] of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]], which places him in the first half of the 8th century BC. According to the book's superscription (Amos 1:1) he was from Tekoa, a town in Judah south of Jerusalem, but his prophetic mission was in the northern kingdom. He is called a "shepherd" and a "dresser of sycamore trees", but the book's literary qualities suggest a man of education rather than a poor farmer.{{sfn|Carroll R.|2003|p=690}}

Scholars have long recognized that Amos utilized an ancient hymn within his prophecy, verses of which are found at 4.13; 5.8–9; 8.8; 9.5–6.<ref>H.W. Wolff, Joel und Amos (Hermeneia; Philadelphia: Fortress Press, 1977), p. 215.</ref> This hymn is best understood as praising YHWH for his judgment, demonstrated in his destructive power, rather than praise for creation.<ref>P. Carny, ‘Doxologies: A Scientific Myth’, Hebrew Studies 18 (1977), pp. 149–59 (157)</ref> Scholarship has also identified [[Lament for Ur|'Sumerian City Lament' (SCL)]] motifs within Amos and particularly the hymn, offering the possibility that Amos used SCL as a literary template for his prophecy of Jerusalem's destruction.<ref>J. Radine, The Book of Amos in Emergent Judah (Tübingen: Mohr Siebeck, 2010)</ref> The Amos hymn has also been discussed in terms of a 'covenant curse' which was used to warn Israel of the consequences of breaking the covenant, and in particular a 'Flood covenant-curse' motif, first identified by D.R. Hillers.<ref>D.R. Hillers, ‘Treaty-Curses and the Old Testament Prophets’ (unpublished PhD dissertation); Rome Pontical Biblical Institute, 1964</ref> Recent scholarship has shown Amos's hymn is an ancient narrative text, has identified a new verse at 7.4; and has compared the hymn to the Genesis Flood account and Job 9:5–10.<ref>G. Cox, "The ‘Hymn’ of Amos: An Ancient Flood Narrative." ''Journal for the Study of the Old Testament'' Vol 38.1 (2013): pp. 81–108</ref>

sections.title: Themes
sections.paragraphs:
The central idea of the book of Amos is that God puts his people on the same level as the surrounding nations – God expects the same purity of them all. As it is with all nations that rise up against the kingdom of God, even Israel and Judah will not be exempt from the judgment of God because of their idolatry and unjust ways. The nation that represents YHWH must be made pure of anything or anyone that profanes the name of God. God's name must be exalted.

Amos is the first prophet to use the term "the [[Day of the Lord]].<ref>Coogan, M. ''A Brief Introduction to the Old Testament: The Hebrew Bible in its Context''. (Oxford University Press: Oxford 2009). p. 260</ref> This phrase becomes important within future prophetic and apocalyptic literature. For the people of Israel "The Day of the Lord" is the day when God will fight against his and their enemies, and it will be a day of victory for Israel. However, Amos and other prophets include Israel as an enemy of God, as Israel is guilty of injustice toward the innocent, poor, and young women.<ref>Coogan, M. ''A Brief Introduction to the Old Testament: The Hebrew Bible in its Context''. Oxford University Press: Oxford, 2009. pp. 258–59.</ref> To Amos "The Day of the Lord" will be a day of doom.

Other major ideas proposed in the book of Amos include: justice and concern for the disadvantaged; that the Hebrew God is God of all nations;  the Hebrew God is judge of all nations;  the Hebrew God is God of moral righteousness;  the Hebrew God made all people; the idea that Israel's [[covenant (biblical)|covenant]] with God did not exempt them from accountability for sin;  God [[Election (Christianity)|elected]] Israel and then liberated Israel so that he would be known throughout the world;  election by God means that those elected are responsible to live according to the purposes clearly outlined to them in the covenant;  if God destroys the unjust, a remnant will remain;  and God is free to judge whether to redeem Israel.
